title: Shortening Fermentation Period and Quality Improvement of Fermented Fish, Chouguiyu, by Co-inoculation of Lactococcus lactis M10 and Weissella cibaria M3
summary: This study investigates the effect of co-inoculation of Lactococcus lactis M10 and Weissella cibaria M3 on the quality improvement and fermentation period shortening of Chouguiyu, a traditional fermented fish. The results show that co-inoculation can promote flavor formation and improve product quality, with a 29% reduction in fermentation time.
methodology: The study used microbiological, physicochemical, volatile, and sensory analyses to evaluate the effect of single starter culture (Lactococcus lactis M10, Weissella cibaria M3), mixed starter culture (Lactoc. lactis M10 and W. cibaria M3), and without starter culture (the control) on Chouguiyu.
research_outcomes: The co-inoculation of Lactococcus lactis M10 and Weissella cibaria M3 was found to have a positive effect on improving the product's quality, with a significant reduction in fermentation time.

title: Changes in the Quality Attributes of Selected Long-Life Food at Four Different Temperatures over Prolonged Storage
summary: This study investigates the changes in quality attributes of long-life food stored at four different temperatures over a two-year period. The research focuses on the effects of storage temperature on the microbiological, chemical, textural, and sensory properties of canned and dehydrated foods.
methodology: The study employed a storage experiment with samples taken immediately after purchase and at regular intervals over 24 months. Microbiological, chemical, textural, and sensory analyses were performed on the stored food products.
research_outcomes: The results show that storage temperature significantly affects the quality attributes of long-life food. The study highlights the importance of considering storage conditions in the development of preservation methods for food products.

title: Yield Response of Winter Squash to Irrigation Regime and Planting Density
summary: This paper investigates the yield response of winter squash to irrigation regime and planting density in western Oregon. The study found that planting density impacted fruit weight, number of fruit per hectare, and number of fruit per plant, but did not impact yield statistically. The results suggest that farmers can manipulate squash fruit size to suit market preferences by changing planting density.
methodology: The study used a split-split plot randomized complete block design experiment with irrigation as the main plot, planting density as the subplot, and variety as the sub-subplot.
research_outcomes: The study found that 'Tetsukabuto' had the greatest yield, number of fruit per hectare, and number of fruit per plant when grown with irrigation. Planting density impacted fruit weight, number of fruit per hectare, and number of fruit per plant.

title: Developing scoring functions to assess soil quality at a regional scale in rangelands of SW Spain
summary: This paper presents a methodology for assessing soil quality at a regional scale using scoring functions. The authors developed standard scoring functions (SSFs) to standardize ten indicators of soil quality, including sand, silt, clay, and others. They used multivariate techniques such as Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to calculate weighting factors for each indicator. The SSFs were applied to 194 soil profiles in the Extremadura region of Spain, resulting in two regional maps of soil quality.
methodology: The authors used a combination of multivariate techniques and scoring functions to assess soil quality at a regional scale. They selected ten indicators of soil quality and calculated weighting factors using PCA and AHP. The SSFs were then applied to the data to standardize each indicator.
statistics: Principal Component Analysis (PCA), Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP)
research_outcomes: The authors developed two regional maps of soil quality, showing remarkable spatial differences in soil quality presumably induced by land management. The methodology presented in this paper could be useful for assessing soil quality at a large scale.

title: Optimization of Pectin Enzymatic Extraction from Malus domestica ‘Fălticeni’ Apple Pomace with Celluclast 1.5L
summary: This paper optimizes pectin extraction from apple pomace using Celluclast 1.5L, a commercially available enzyme preparation. The study uses response surface methodology to investigate the effects of temperature, time, and enzyme dose on pectin yield and composition.
methodology: Response Surface Methodology (RSM) with Box-Behnken design
research_outcomes: Optimized conditions for pectin extraction: temperature of 48.3 °C, extraction time of 18 h 14 min, and enzyme dose of 42.5 µL/g of pomace.

title: Esophageal groove dysfunction: a cause of ruminal bloat in newborn calves
summary: This paper investigates the causes of ruminal bloat in newborn calves, specifically focusing on esophageal groove dysfunction. The authors present a case study of a 10-day-old calf that developed severe abdominal distention and was treated with rumenostomy to prevent recurrence.
methodology: The paper uses a combination of clinical observations, physical examination, and laboratory tests to diagnose esophageal groove dysfunction in the calf. The authors also describe the treatment approach, which included administering antibiotics and IV fluids.
research_outcomes: The study found that esophageal groove dysfunction is a significant cause of ruminal bloat in newborn calves. The authors conclude that rumenostomy can be an effective treatment for preventing recurrence of the condition.

title: The Effect of Topical Anaesthesia on the Cortisol Responses of Calves Undergoing Dehorning
summary: This study investigates the effect of topical anaesthesia on cortisol responses in calves undergoing dehorning. The researchers found that while the topical anaesthetic reduced wound sensitivity, it had no significant impact on cortisol concentrations.
methodology: The study used a randomized controlled trial design to evaluate the effect of a modified post-operative topical wound management formulation containing two local anaesthetics on plasma cortisol concentration in calves undergoing dehorning.
research_outcomes: The study found that the topical anaesthetic reduced wound sensitivity, but had no significant impact on cortisol concentrations. The researchers suggest that a multimodal analgesic approach should be used to improve animal welfare in dehorning procedures.

title: Comparative Antimicrobial Effectiveness of Two Medicated Soaps with Herbal Soap from Morinda morindoides (Rubiaceae) against Skin Pathogens
summary: This paper investigates the antimicrobial effectiveness of two medicated soaps and a herbal soap formulated with fat extracted from Morinda morindoides against skin pathogens. The study found that all three soaps have antimicrobial activity, but the herbal soap was more effective than the medicated soaps.
methodology: The authors used agar broth dilution method and agar plate method to determine the antimicrobial parameters of the soaps.
research_outcomes: All three soaps showed significant antimicrobial activity, with the herbal soap being more effective than the medicated soaps.

title: A seven-gene-deleted African swine fever virus is safe and effective as a live attenuated vaccine in pigs
summary: This paper presents the development of a live attenuated vaccine against African swine fever (ASF) using a seven-gene-deleted virus. The study demonstrates that the vaccine is safe and effective in pigs, providing complete protection against lethal ASFV challenge.
methodology: The methodology involves generating a series of gene-deleted viruses from the Chinese ASFV HLJ/18 as a backbone, followed by evaluation of their virulence, immunogenicity, safety, and protective efficacy in specific-pathogen-free pigs, commercial pigs, and pregnant sows.
research_outcomes: The study shows that one virus, namely HLJ/18-7GD, is fully attenuated in pigs, cannot convert to the virulent strain, and provides complete protection of pigs against lethal ASFV challenge.

title: Integrating Ecosystem Services Supply, Demand and Flow in Ecological Compensation: A Case Study of Carbon Sequestration Services
summary: This paper focuses on the integration of ecosystem services supply, demand, and flow in ecological compensation. It uses a case study of carbon sequestration services in Yantai to assess the ecological benefits and measure the amount of ecological compensation. The study combines physical measurement and monetary measurement from the perspective of ecosystem services supply and demand.
methodology: The study used land change survey data, population density data, elevation data, slope data, and other data to assess the ecological benefits of carbon sequestration services in Yantai.
research_outcomes: The results showed that most areas of Yantai belonged to the ecological surplus area, which were important sources of carbon sequestration services. Ecological compensation was needed, with a total amount of about 2.2 billion yuan.

title: Nutritional, Functional, and Technological Characterization of a Novel Gluten- and Lactose-Free Yogurt-Style Snack Produced With Selected Lactic Acid Bacteria and Leguminosae Flours
summary: This paper presents a novel biotechnological protocol for producing a gluten-free, lactose-free yogurt-style snack using selected lactic acid bacteria and leguminosae flours. The study focuses on the nutritional, functional, and sensory properties of the fermented snack, with no mention of machine learning or artificial intelligence methods.
methodology: The biotechnological protocol involves fermentation by selected lactic acid bacteria (LAB) Lactoplantibacillus plantarum DSM33326 and Levilactobacillus brevis DSM33325 on a blend of rice, lentil, and chickpea flours.
research_outcomes: The study found improved nutritional features, such as increased protein digestibility and lower concentrations of antinutritional factors, in the fermented snack compared to the unfermented matrix. The sensory profile was also enhanced.

title: High-Altitude Genetic Selection and Genome-Wide Association Analysis of Yield-Related Traits in Elymus sibiricus L. Using SLAF Sequencing
summary: This study investigates the genetic adaptations of Elymus sibiricus L. to high-altitude environments using SLAF sequencing and genome-wide association analysis. The research identifies key genes involved in response to UV radiation, flavonoid, and anthocyanin biosynthesis, and provides insights into hub genes controlling plant height traits.
methodology: The study used a mixed linear model (MLM) for genome-wide association analysis and identified significant loci associated with agronomic traits. The authors also employed SLAF sequencing to identify single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs).
research_outcomes: The study found 965 alleles under natural selection of high altitude and identified 7 hub genes involved in response to UV radiation. The GWAS test identified a total of 1,825 significant loci associated with 12 agronomic traits.

title: The Effect of K-Carrageenan Addition to the Characteristics of Jicama Starch-Based Edible Coating and Its Potential Application on The Grapevine
summary: This paper investigates the effect of k-carrageenan addition to jicama starch-based edible coating on its physical and chemical characteristics, as well as its potential application on grapevine. The study finds that k-carrageenan significantly influences the thickness, moisture content, tensile strength value, and WVTR value of the produced edible coating.
methodology: The research used a randomized design with one addition factor (k-carrageenan) and analyzed the data using variance analysis and Duncan's differential analysis.
research_outcomes: The study found that k-carrageenan addition was significantly influenced the thickness, moisture content, tensile strength value, and WVTR value of the produced edible coating. Treatment A5 has produced films with good physical characteristics.

title: Assessing functional properties of rapeseed protein concentrate versus isolate for food applications
summary: This paper compares the functional properties of rapeseed protein concentrates and isolates, exploring their potential applications in food industry. The study focuses on the effects of different processing conditions on the techno-functional properties of rapeseed materials, including rheological properties, water binding capacity, and particle hydration.
methodology: The authors employed various methods to fractionate and characterize the functional properties of rapeseed protein concentrates and isolates. These included aqueous ethanolic washing, ultrafiltration, dialysis, and freeze-drying.
research_outcomes: The study found that the processing conditions significantly affected the techno-functional properties of rapeseed materials. The authors identified potential applications for these materials in food industry, including meat analogue or other food products.

title: Parasitic Contamination of Fresh Vegetables in Open Air Markets of Aksum, Ethiopia
summary: This study assesses the parasitic contamination level of fresh vegetables in open air markets of Aksum, Ethiopia. The research focuses on identifying factors associated with vegetable contamination and determining the prevalence of parasites in various vegetable samples. Machine learning or AI methods are not used in this paper.
methodology: The study employed a random sample collection method to gather 384 vegetable samples from six types, including lettuce, cabbage, spinach, pepper, potato, and tomato. The samples were analyzed using parasitological examination techniques, including centrifugation, sedimentation, and microscopic analysis.
research_outcomes: The study found a high prevalence of parasitic contamination in fresh vegetables, with 57.3% of the samples containing at least one parasite. The most frequently detected parasites were Taenia spp., Enetrobius vermicularis egg, and Hookworm spp. egg.

title: Advanced Characterization of Monoﬂoral Honeys from Romania
summary: This paper focuses on the characterization of monoﬂoral honeys from Romania using various analytical methods, including pollen analysis, FT-IR spectroscopy, and rheological properties. The study aims to determine the botanical origin of seven samples of monoﬂoral honey based on their physicochemical characteristics.
methodology: The paper employs a combination of traditional and non-destructive methods for analyzing the honey samples, including pollen analysis, FT-IR spectroscopy, rheological properties, and differential scanning calorimetry.
statistics: ANOVA using Statgraphics Centurion XIX software
research_outcomes: The study found that the highest percentage of pollen grains was identified in sunflower honey (90%), followed by acacia honey with a percentage of Rubus pollen (78%). The moisture content varied between 15.25 and 17.31%, which is within the allowed limits.

title: Overexpression of a Novel Apple NAC Transcription Factor Gene, MdNAC1, Confers the Dwarf Phenotype in Transgenic Apple (Malus domestica)
summary: This paper investigates the function of MdNAC1, a novel NAC transcription factor gene in apple, and its role in plant dwarfism. The overexpression of MdNAC1 leads to a dwarf phenotype in transgenic apple plants, with shorter stems, roots, and leaf areas. The study reveals that MdNAC1 regulates the biosynthesis of ABA and BR, providing new insights into dwarfism.
methodology: The authors used a combination of molecular biology techniques, including PCR, sequencing, and yeast two-hybrid assays, to study the function of MdNAC1. They also performed phylogenetic analysis and gene structure examination using bioinformatics tools.
research_outcomes: The overexpression of MdNAC1 leads to a dwarf phenotype in transgenic apple plants, with shorter stems, roots, and leaf areas. The study reveals that MdNAC1 regulates the biosynthesis of ABA and BR.

title: Wheat CBL-interacting protein kinase 25 negatively regulates salt tolerance in transgenic wheat
summary: This paper investigates the role of TaCIPK25 in regulating salt response in wheat. The study found that overexpression of TaCIPK25 resulted in hypersensitivity to Na+ and superfluous accumulation of Na+ in transgenic wheat lines, indicating a negative regulation of salt tolerance.
methodology: The study used quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) and yeast one-hybrid (Y1H) assays to analyze the expression patterns of TaCIPK25 in response to salt and ABA application.
research_outcomes: The results showed that TaCIPK25 down-regulated expressions induced by NaCl were involved in ABA signaling pathway. The study also found that overexpression of TaCIPK25 impaired salt tolerance in Arabidopsis.

title: A strategy for qualitative and quantitative profiling of glycyrrhiza extract and discovery of potential markers by fingerprint-activity relationship modeling
summary: This study evaluates the quality consistency of glycyrrhiza extract and explores anti-oxidant components using chromatographic fingerprint and bioactivity evaluation. The research uses machine learning methods to analyze HPLC fingerprints, but ML is not central to the methodology.
methodology: The study uses high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with diode array detection (DAD) to generate characteristic fingerprints of glycyrrhiza extract samples from different sources. Hierarchical clustering and similarity analysis are used to evaluate the quality consistency.
research_outcomes: The study provides a powerful strategy for evaluating the holistic quality consistency of medicinal plants using chromatographic fingerprint and bioactivity evaluation. The results show that the fusion fingerprint evaluation strategy is comprehensive and indispensable for avoiding potential deviations from single wavelength.

title: Creating functional foodstuffs from high-technological larval raw materials
summary: This paper explores the development of new functional food products using apiproducts from drone larvae, which are rich in high-grade protein and biologically active substances. The research aims to address the global problem of food shortages and nutritional deficiencies by enriching food products with vital nutrients.
methodology: The authors developed recipes for new functional bakery, confectionery, and honey products using apiproducts from drone larvae, which were manufactured at a small innovative enterprise Apiproduct Ltd.
research_outcomes: The study demonstrated the possibility of manufacturing functional foodstuffs with high-grade protein and biologically active substances, which can improve many physiological processes in the human body.

title: Adaption of Wheat Genotypes to Drought Stress
summary: This paper investigates the adaptability and suitability of six wheat genotypes under harsh drought conditions. The study uses phenotypic markers to screen for drought-tolerant wheat genotypes, with a focus on morphological parameters such as stem length, spike length, and awns length.
methodology: Phenotypic markers were used to evaluate the adaptability of six wheat genotypes under drought conditions. The study employed a Randomized Complete Block (RCB) design with three replicate sites.
research_outcomes: The results showed significant variations among the six wheat genotypes for most of the measured parameters. Yellow-Hetia genotype presented the highest stem length, spike length, and awns length, while Nab-El-Jamal genotype exhibited the lowest grain production.

title: Analysis of Intensity, Duration, and Frequency Rain Daily of Java Island Using Mononobe Method
summary: This paper analyzes rainfall intensity in Java Island using the Mononobe method, aiming to determine short-term rain duration and frequency. The study uses annual rainfall data from 2005-2019 for six provinces in Java, calculating daily rainfall intensity and return periods. The results show that West Java Province has high rainfall compared to other provinces, while Banten Province has the lowest rainfall.
methodology: The Mononobe method is used to analyze rainfall intensity, with data collected from 2005-2019 for six provinces in Java. The study calculates daily rainfall intensity and return periods using the Gumbel formula.
research_outcomes: The study finds that West Java Province has high rainfall compared to other provinces, while Banten Province has the lowest rainfall. The results also show that the largest increase in rain intensity occurred in the period 10-25 years.

title: Asymmetric Reciprocal Crossing Behavior of an Andean Blueberry (V. meridionale) × Lingonberry (V. vitis-idaea) Hybrid
summary: This paper investigates the asymmetric reciprocal crossing behavior of a tetraploid hybrid between Andean blueberry (V. meridionale) and lingonberry (V. vitis-idaea). The study focuses on the fertility and crossing behavior of this hybrid, exploring its potential for breeding highbush blueberries.
methodology: The authors used a series of crosses to evaluate the fertility and crossing behavior of the tetraploid hybrid. They also employed flow cytometry to determine the ploidy levels of the offspring.
research_outcomes: The study found that the tetraploid hybrid can produce both hexaploid and tetraploid offspring, depending on the parent used in the cross. The authors also identified a new method for producing fertile hybrids between V. meridionale and highbush blueberry.

title: Fine mapping qGL2H, a major locus controlling grain length in barley (Hordeum vulgare L.)
summary: This paper focuses on fine mapping a major grain length QTL, qGL2H, in barley. The study uses a doubled haploid population and extensive genotypic and phenotypic data to identify a 140.9 Kb region containing three genes that contribute to grain length and yield.
methodology: The authors used a combination of genotypic and phenotypic data from field trials to fine map the qGL2H locus. They employed linear mixed models to calculate best linear unbiased predictions (BLUPs) for grain size characteristics and yield.
research_outcomes: The study identified a major grain length QTL, qGL2H, on chromosome 2H that explained 25.4% of the phenotypic variation for grain length and 10.2% for grain yield. The underlying gene represents a promising target for future genetic research.

title: Heats of Combustion Representative of Carbohydrate Mass Contained in Fruits, Vegetables, or Cereals
summary: This paper focuses on the measurement of heat of combustion for six carbohydrates (glucose, fructose, sucrose, maltose, starch, and cellulose) to improve the estimation of metabolizable energy. The study uses a calorimetric method to measure the heat of combustion, with results showing that Atwater's value overestimates the heat of combustion in vegetable source foods.
methodology: The authors used a calorimetric method to measure the heat of combustion for six carbohydrates. The measurements were performed using an isoperibolic calorimeter and benzoic acid as a reference material.
research_outcomes: The study found that Atwater's value overestimates the heat of combustion in vegetable source foods. The authors proposed new representative values for the heat of combustion of each carbohydrate, which can be used to estimate metabolizable energy.
